channel.title: Got a car!
channel.description: Well i got my first car, its a second-hand Ford KA. Its kind of a girly car and its category x so it was cheap :D me and my dad are gonna fix and sell so i can buy a not so girly car :P any ideas on what i should get? i should be able to insure it bear in mind and afford to run it!

item.title: Got a car!
item.dc:creator: @Brett2 Brett`
item.description:
@Brett2 wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:29, topic:225213”]My first is a 1994 Ranger XLT. I have it pimped up nicely. 2000 dollar speaker system, 4" suspension kit, lights along the top, truck bars…

I myself have owned allot of cars, mostly Japanese cars (<3 JDM).

Let me advise you on a car when you just got your license.
A Nissan S13 (I would prefer a S14) is very nice and fust, but it isn’t a car for beginning drivers.
The reason for this is first of al: Power + turbo and rear wheel drive.

If you don’t have any expierience at all with driving you will end up crashing sooner than you think with RWD, this is because the slightest error in a corner will be punished HARD, for example: You’re cutting a corner, and in the apex of the corner you push the pedal like you would with a FWD car, with FWD this is possible but however with RWD your backend will breakout and if you don’t correct you will find your self reversed, or sliding off the road.
Plus those S13/S14 are mostely 2.0 Turbo engines, I don’t know if you got any expierience with normal turbo engines (not diesel) they aren’t easy to drive for a beginning driver, because you don’t get the full power from idle RPM like a supercharger, you get a kick in the back from a turbo and in the case of a S13/S14 it starts at 3.500 RPM.

Err if someone can’t drive RWD they shouldn’t be driving on the roads period, imo. I don’t even know if I’ve ever driven a FWD vehicle.[/quote]

Yeah, I don’t think I have either. they’re really fun in the winter if you know how to drive them right!
'93 Lincoln town car. I drive a boat too school.

Read full topic

item.title: Got a car!
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

My first is a 1994 Ranger XLT. I have it pimped up nicely. 2000 dollar speaker system, 4" suspension kit, lights along the top, truck bars…

[quote=“Waffendennis, post:20, topic:225213”]I myself have owned allot of cars, mostly Japanese cars (<3 JDM).

Let me advise you on a car when you just got your license.
A Nissan S13 (I would prefer a S14) is very nice and fust, but it isn’t a car for beginning drivers.
The reason for this is first of al: Power + turbo and rear wheel drive.

If you don’t have any expierience at all with driving you will end up crashing sooner than you think with RWD, this is because the slightest error in a corner will be punished HARD, for example: You’re cutting a corner, and in the apex of the corner you push the pedal like you would with a FWD car, with FWD this is possible but however with RWD your backend will breakout and if you don’t correct you will find your self reversed, or sliding off the road.
Plus those S13/S14 are mostely 2.0 Turbo engines, I don’t know if you got any expierience with normal turbo engines (not diesel) they aren’t easy to drive for a beginning driver, because you don’t get the full power from idle RPM like a supercharger, you get a kick in the back from a turbo and in the case of a S13/S14 it starts at 3.500 RPM.[/quote]

Err if someone can’t drive RWD they shouldn’t be driving on the roads period, imo. I don’t even know if I’ve ever driven a FWD vehicle.

Read full topic

item.title: Got a car!
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Waffendennis, post:20, topic:225213”]I myself have owned allot of cars, mostly Japanese cars (<3 JDM).

Let me advise you on a car when you just got your license.
A Nissan S13 (I would prefer a S14) is very nice and fust, but it isn’t a car for beginning drivers.
The reason for this is first of al: Power + turbo and rear wheel drive.

If you don’t have any expierience at all with driving you will end up crashing sooner than you think with RWD, this is because the slightest error in a corner will be punished HARD, for example: You’re cutting a corner, and in the apex of the corner you push the pedal like you would with a FWD car, with FWD this is possible but however with RWD your backend will breakout and if you don’t correct you will find your self reversed, or sliding off the road.
Plus those S13/S14 are mostely 2.0 Turbo engines, I don’t know if you got any expierience with normal turbo engines (not diesel) they aren’t easy to drive for a beginning driver, because you don’t get the full power from idle RPM like a supercharger, you get a kick in the back from a turbo and in the case of a S13/S14 it starts at 3.500 RPM.

I’d say go with toyota, or better yet go with Honda.
Few months ago I got myself a black Honda Civic hatchback from '92. It’s totally remodded.
The car came with a 1.6l D16Z6 SOHC VTEC engine (good for 130HP on 900KG), I swapped it for a 1.8l DOHC VTEC B18C-R engine (good for 220HP on 900KG). At the moment it’s getting turbo mounted, so far the car runs 469HP @ 0.2 bar. The car is ment for circuit because it isn’t quite handy on the streets.[/quote]
I was definately thinking of going japanese and as for driving exxperience that is something i do have i did some days at rockingham race circuit, driving on and off the track but i agree with getting a rear wheel drive, there is no point in making a front wheel drive car it gives the wheels too much to do resulting in understeer.

[quote=“Swordskid61, post:24, topic:225213”]I got my first car too

12207-1992-Ford-Mustang.jpg1024×768

92 mustang ftw[/quote]
No offence but you bought the wrong decade of mustangs the 90’s were meagre compared to the 70’s

Read full topic

item.title: Got a car!
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

Get a Volvo. A very safe reliable car. My first car was a 1991 Volvo 240 Station Wago. The thing was a tank. Then I got a Dodge Ram 1500, pretty good gas mileage for a pickup. And then a '98 Escalade, the worst of the three. But if you get a Volvo, their steering is real sensitive, which was always a pain in the ass.
